title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 20 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Chronicles chapter 20 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 20 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Chronicles Chapter 20.

questions.question: Who led the army to waste the country of the children of Ammon?
questions.correctAnswer: Joab
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 20:1 states that Joab led forth the power of the army and wasted the country of the children of Ammon.

questions.question: What did David take from the king of the children of Ammon?
questions.correctAnswer: The crown
questions.explanation: According to 1 Chronicles 20:2, David took the crown of their king from off his head.

questions.question: How much did the crown David took weigh?
questions.correctAnswer: A talent of gold
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 20:2 describes the crown as weighing a talent of gold.

questions.question: What cruel methods did David use on the people taken from the cities of Ammon?
options: Cut them with saws, harrows of iron, and axes
questions.correctAnswer: Cut them with saws, harrows of iron, and axes
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 20:3 states David cut the people with saws, harrows of iron, and axes.

questions.question: Who killed Sippai, the giant among the Philistines at Gezer?
questions.correctAnswer: Sibbechai the Hushathite
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 20:4 tells us Sibbechai the Hushathite slew Sippai at Gezer.

questions.question: Who killed Lahmi, the brother of Goliath?
questions.correctAnswer: Elhanan the son of Jair
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 20:5 states that Elhanan the son of Jair slew Lahmi, the brother of Goliath.

questions.question: Where was the giant with six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot from?
questions.correctAnswer: Gath
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 20:6 mentions a giant of great stature in Gath with extra fingers and toes.

questions.question: Who killed the giant from Gath who defied Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Jonathan the son of Shimea
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 20:7 says Jonathan the son of Shimea, David's brother, slew the giant who defied Israel.

questions.question: True or False: David personally led the siege of Rabbah while Joab stayed in Jerusalem.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 20:1 states Joab led the siege of Rabbah while David tarried at Jerusalem.

questions.question: True or False: The crown David took was adorned with precious stones.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 20:2 confirms the crown had precious stones in it.

questions.question: True or False: All the giants born in Gath fell by the hand of David and his servants.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 20:8 explains that the giants in Gath fell by the hand of David and his servants.

questions.question: Complete the verse from 1 Chronicles 20:1: 'And Joab smote Rabbah, and ______ it.'
questions.correctAnswer: destroyed
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 20:1 states that Joab smote Rabbah and destroyed it.

questions.question: What was the spear staff of Lahmi compared to?
questions.correctAnswer: A weaver's beam
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 20:5 describes Lahmi's spear staff as like a weaver's beam.

questions.question: What time of year did Joab lead the army against the children of Ammon?
options: At the time that kings go out to battle
questions.correctAnswer: At the time that kings go out to battle
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 20:1 indicates Joab led the army after the year expired, at the time kings go out to battle.

questions.question: Who was Jonathan's father according to the chapter?
questions.correctAnswer: Shimea
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 20:7 calls Jonathan the son of Shimea, David's brother.

medium.title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 20 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Chronicles Chapter 20 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with patience while waiting for God’s timing. Based on 1 Chronicles 20:1-3, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God during battles or trials?
options: God often uses others to accomplish His work while we wait in faith.
We must fight all battles ourselves without relying on others.
Waiting means God is not involved in the situation.
Immediate action without faith is always best.
questions.correctAnswer: God often uses others to accomplish His work while we wait in faith.
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 20:1 shows that Joab led the army while David stayed in Jerusalem, indicating that God can use others to work on our behalf as we trust Him. This teaches patience and trust in God's timing.

questions.question: How does 1 Chronicles 20:2 teach us about the importance of stewardship and generosity in God’s blessings?
options: David took the king’s crown, symbolizing responsible stewardship of what God provides.
David kept all the spoil for himself without sharing.
David ignored the spoils and gave nothing to God.
David only took small gifts from the city.
questions.correctAnswer: David took the king’s crown, symbolizing responsible stewardship of what God provides.
questions.explanation: Verse 2 describes David taking the crown and spoil, which reflects the responsibility to manage God’s blessings wisely, encouraging us to be good stewards of what God entrusts to us.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with anger and vengeance. Based on 1 Chronicles 20:3, what biblical caution can be learned about dealing with enemies?
options: Harsh treatment of others can lead to unnecessary cruelty and is not encouraged.
We should always seek revenge immediately.
We should ignore wrongdoing and do nothing.
We must always respond with violence.
questions.correctAnswer: Harsh treatment of others can lead to unnecessary cruelty and is not encouraged.
questions.explanation: Verse 3 shows David’s harsh treatment of captives, which serves as a cautionary example. Scripture elsewhere teaches forgiveness and love for enemies, encouraging us to avoid cruelty.

questions.question: What does the account of Sibbechai slaying Sippai in 1 Chronicles 20:4 teach us about courage and trusting God in spiritual battles?
options: God empowers the faithful to overcome giants and challenges.
questions.correctAnswer: God empowers the faithful to overcome giants and challenges.
questions.explanation: Verse 4 highlights Sibbechai’s victory over a giant, demonstrating that faith and reliance on God empower believers to face and overcome their challenges.

questions.question: How should believers apply the story of Elhanan slaying Lahmi (1 Chronicles 20:5) to their work ethic and integrity?
options: Diligence and courage in one’s duties bring God’s blessing and victory.
Avoid work that seems difficult or dangerous.
Only leaders should engage in challenges.
Success depends on luck, not effort.
questions.correctAnswer: Diligence and courage in one’s duties bring God’s blessing and victory.
questions.explanation: Verse 5 shows Elhanan’s courageous work in battle, encouraging believers to approach their responsibilities with diligence and trust God for success.

questions.question: A believer feels overwhelmed by the size of their challenges. Based on 1 Chronicles 20:6-7, what biblical truth about perseverance would you share?
options: Even the largest obstacles can be overcome through faith, courage, and support from others.
Big problems are impossible to solve and should be avoided.
Only physical strength can defeat challenges.
Challenges are a sign God has abandoned us.
questions.correctAnswer: Even the largest obstacles can be overcome through faith, courage, and support from others.
questions.explanation: Verses 6-7 describe a giant defeated by Jonathan, emphasizing that with faith and courage, no obstacle is insurmountable, and support from others is vital.

questions.question: What does the repeated theme of defeating giants in 1 Chronicles 20 teach about spiritual perseverance during trials?
options: God strengthens believers to overcome persistent spiritual battles.
Trials are meant to defeat us permanently.
Victory is based on human effort alone.
questions.correctAnswer: God strengthens believers to overcome persistent spiritual battles.
questions.explanation: Verses 4-8 collectively show multiple victories over giants, symbolizing God’s power to help believers persevere through ongoing spiritual challenges.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Chronicles 20:1, David personally led the army in besieging Rabbah.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 1 states Joab led the army while David stayed in Jerusalem, showing David did not personally lead the siege.

questions.question: True or False: 1 Chronicles 20 teaches that humility in leadership includes trusting others to carry out God’s work.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: David’s decision to remain in Jerusalem while Joab led the army (verse 1) illustrates humility and trust in others to fulfill God's purposes.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jonathan the son of Shimea, David’s brother, slew a giant who defied Israel at _______.
questions.correctAnswer: Gath
questions.explanation: Verse 7 specifies Jonathan slew the giant at Gath, showing God’s deliverance through family and courage.

questions.question: Based on 1 Chronicles 20:2, what does placing the Ammonite king’s crown on David’s head teach about humility and gratitude?
options: Acknowledging God’s provision through symbols of victory should be met with humility and gratitude.
Taking trophies for pride is encouraged.
Only physical strength matters in victory.
questions.correctAnswer: Acknowledging God’s provision through symbols of victory should be met with humility and gratitude.
questions.explanation: David’s act of placing the crown on his head (verse 2) signifies recognition of God’s blessing and the need for humility and thankfulness.

questions.question: How does 1 Chronicles 20:4-5 illustrate the role of teamwork and supporting each other in the body of Christ?
options: Multiple warriors working together show the importance of mutual support in spiritual battles.
Only one person can fight alone.
Teamwork is not necessary in spiritual matters.
Each person should work independently without help.
questions.correctAnswer: Multiple warriors working together show the importance of mutual support in spiritual battles.
questions.explanation: Verses 4-5 mention different individuals defeating giants, indicating that many members contribute in God’s work, encouraging teamwork and service.

questions.question: What lesson about perseverance can be drawn from the repeated wars described in 1 Chronicles 20:4-8?
options: Faithfulness and persistence in trials lead to eventual victory.
Giving up is the best option when facing repeated challenges.
questions.correctAnswer: Faithfulness and persistence in trials lead to eventual victory.
questions.explanation: The multiple wars and victories (verses 4-8) show that perseverance through repeated trials is rewarded by God.

questions.question: How does 1 Chronicles 20:3 challenge believers to consider the ethics of their actions even when victorious?
options: Victory should be tempered with mercy and ethical treatment of others.
Cruelty in victory is always justified.
Ethics do not matter in battle.
questions.correctAnswer: Victory should be tempered with mercy and ethical treatment of others.
questions.explanation: Verse 3’s harsh treatment of captives serves as a reminder to balance victory with mercy and ethical conduct, aligning with biblical love and forgiveness.

questions.question: What does the account of defeating giants in 1 Chronicles 20 teach about humility and reliance on God rather than physical might?
options: True strength comes from God’s power, not human size or strength.
Only the biggest and strongest win.
Physical might is the only factor in victory.
God’s power is irrelevant in battles.
questions.correctAnswer: True strength comes from God’s power, not human size or strength.
questions.explanation: The giants’ size contrasted with their defeat (verses 4-8) highlights that reliance on God’s power, not human might, leads to victory.

hard.title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 20 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Chronicles Chapter 20.

questions.question: Who led the army against the children of Ammon and besieged Rabbah while David remained in Jerusalem?
questions.correctAnswer: Joab
questions.explanation: Joab led the power of the army against the children of Ammon and besieged Rabbah while David tarried at Jerusalem, as stated in 1 Chronicles 20:1.

questions.question: What was the weight and composition of the crown taken from the king of the children of Ammon?
options: A talent of gold with precious stones
questions.correctAnswer: A talent of gold with precious stones
questions.explanation: David took the crown which weighed a talent of gold and had precious stones, as noted in 1 Chronicles 20:2.

questions.question: What brutal method did David use against the people taken from the cities of the children of Ammon?
options: Cut them with saws, harrows of iron, and axes
questions.correctAnswer: Cut them with saws, harrows of iron, and axes
questions.explanation: David dealt harshly by cutting the people with saws, harrows of iron, and axes, as described in 1 Chronicles 20:3.

questions.question: Which Philistine giant was killed by Sibbechai the Hushathite during the war at Gezer?
options: The giant with 24 fingers and toes
questions.correctAnswer: Sippai
questions.explanation: Sibbechai the Hushathite slew Sippai, who was of the children of the giant, during the war at Gezer as recorded in 1 Chronicles 20:4.

questions.question: Who killed Lahmi, the brother of Goliath, and what is notable about Lahmi's spear?
options: Elhanan, whose spear staff was like a weaver's beam
Jonathan, whose spear was made of iron
Joab, whose spear was long and sharp
Sibbechai, whose spear was decorated with gold
questions.correctAnswer: Elhanan, whose spear staff was like a weaver's beam
questions.explanation: Elhanan son of Jair killed Lahmi, and Lahmi's spear staff was like a weaver's beam, as indicated in 1 Chronicles 20:5.

questions.question: At which Philistine city did a giant with 24 fingers and toes, six on each hand and foot, appear?
questions.correctAnswer: Gath
questions.explanation: The man of great stature with 24 fingers and toes was at Gath, as described in 1 Chronicles 20:6.

questions.question: Who slew the giant from Gath who defied Israel, and what was his relation to David?
questions.correctAnswer: Jonathan, David's brother
questions.explanation: Jonathan, son of Shimea and David’s brother, slew the giant from Gath who defied Israel, as noted in 1 Chronicles 20:7.

questions.question: What is the significance of the repeated mention of giants and their defeat by David and his servants in 1 Chronicles 20?
options: It emphasizes the divine empowerment of David's house over Israel’s enemies
It illustrates the futility of opposing Israel militarily
It typifies the spiritual battle between good and evil
questions.correctAnswer: All of the above
questions.explanation: The repeated defeats of giants foreshadow divine empowerment, Israel's military supremacy, and spiritual victory themes, reflecting authorial intent and theological motifs throughout Scripture, as gathered from the entire chapter.

questions.question: True or False: David personally led the siege and destruction of Rabbah.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: David tarried at Jerusalem while Joab led and smote Rabbah, as stated in 1 Chronicles 20:1.

questions.question: The Hebrew term for 'giant' used in this chapter likely connects to which Old Testament giant mentioned in 1 Samuel?
questions.correctAnswer: Goliath
questions.explanation: The giants referenced relate to Goliath and his kin from 1 Samuel, establishing intertextual connection with 1 Chronicles 20:4-8.

questions.question: What literary device is evident in the parallel accounts of warriors killing giants in this chapter?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: The repeated patterns of giants being slain by named warriors illustrate parallelism, a common Hebrew literary feature, as seen throughout 1 Chronicles 20:4-8.

questions.question: The phrase 'spear staff was like a weaver's beam' most likely emphasizes what about Lahmi's weapon?
options: Its symbolic weaving of Israel's fate
questions.correctAnswer: Its exceptional size and weight
questions.explanation: The comparison to a weaver’s beam highlights the great size and heaviness of Lahmi’s spear, emphasizing the giant's formidable strength, per 1 Chronicles 20:5.

questions.question: Which theme present in 1 Chronicles 20 reflects the broader biblical motif of God empowering His chosen leader?
options: Divine victory over enemies through David and his warriors
questions.correctAnswer: Divine victory over enemies through David and his warriors
questions.explanation: The repeated defeats of enemies through David and his servants underscore God’s empowerment of His anointed king, a major biblical theme evident in 1 Chronicles 20.

questions.question: What historical or cultural context does the brutal treatment of Ammonite captives by David reflect?
options: Ancient Near Eastern warfare customs involving harsh punitive measures
A unique Israelite practice of mercy
An early form of judicial trial
questions.correctAnswer: Ancient Near Eastern warfare customs involving harsh punitive measures
questions.explanation: The severe treatment of captives aligns with known ancient Near Eastern practices of warfare and punishment, as illustrated in 1 Chronicles 20:3.

questions.question: Which of the following best explains the authorial intent behind recording multiple episodes of giants being slain in this chapter?
options: To demonstrate the comprehensive conquest of Israel’s enemies by David's house
To highlight the military prowess of Joab exclusively
To focus on David’s personal combat achievements
To provide a genealogy of Philistine warriors
questions.correctAnswer: To demonstrate the comprehensive conquest of Israel’s enemies by David's house
questions.explanation: The chronicler emphasizes the widespread defeat of giants by David and his servants to show the extent of Israel’s victories under Davidic leadership, as in 1 Chronicles 20:8.

theological.title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 20 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Chronicles Chapter 20 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What theological significance can be drawn from David placing the Ammonite king's crown upon his own head?
options: It symbolizes God's sovereign authority over nations through His anointed king
It indicates David's personal ambition for power
It represents a pagan ritual of conquest
It was a political alliance between Israel and Ammon
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes God's sovereign authority over nations through His anointed king
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 20:2 shows David taking the crown from the Ammonite king and placing it on his own head, symbolizing God's sovereign rule manifested through David as His anointed king. This reflects God's control over nations as in Psalm 2:6-9 and Romans 13:1, where earthly authority derives from God. Jesus is the ultimate fulfillment of this divine kingship (Revelation 19:16).

questions.question: According to 1 Chronicles 20, what does the repeated warfare against giants teach about God's provision for His people?
options: God empowers His servants to overcome seemingly insurmountable obstacles
Giants symbolize invincible evil that cannot be defeated
Victory is solely due to Israel's military might
The giants were ignored because they were not a threat
questions.correctAnswer: God empowers His servants to overcome seemingly insurmountable obstacles
questions.explanation: Verses 4-8 describe David's servants defeating giants, emphasizing God's empowerment over daunting foes. This aligns with themes like David's confidence in God (1 Samuel 17:45-47), God's strength overcoming evil (Psalm 18:29), and Christ's victory over Satan (Colossians 2:15).

questions.question: What doctrinal truth is illustrated by Joab leading the army while David remains in Jerusalem during the siege of Rabbah?
options: God establishes order in leadership and delegates authority within His kingdom
David was shirking his kingly duty
Military success depends solely on human commanders
Kings should never delegate battle responsibilities
questions.correctAnswer: God establishes order in leadership and delegates authority within His kingdom
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 20:1 shows Joab leading battle while David stays in Jerusalem. This reflects God’s design for ordered authority and delegation (Romans 13:1-4), showing that God works through human institutions and offices for His purposes (Exodus 18:13-26).

questions.question: What does the severe treatment of the captured Ammonites (cutting with saws and iron harrows) reveal about the biblical view of sin and judgment?
options: It reflects the serious consequences of persistent rebellion against God
It promotes cruelty as a virtue
It shows that God condones torture
It was a cultural practice unrelated to divine justice
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects the serious consequences of persistent rebellion against God
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 20:3 describes harsh judgment on the Ammonites, illustrating that sin and rebellion against God bring severe consequences (Romans 1:18-32). This is consistent with divine justice seen in Old Testament judgments (Deuteronomy 28) and New Testament warnings (Hebrews 10:26-31).

questions.question: How does the mention of the giant’s fingers and toes being twenty-four in number (six on each hand and foot) contribute to the biblical portrayal of evil?
options: It symbolizes the unnatural and monstrous nature of evil forces opposing God
It is a historical exaggeration with no spiritual meaning
It shows that physical size determines spiritual power
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the unnatural and monstrous nature of evil forces opposing God
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 20:6 highlights the abnormal physical traits of the giant, symbolizing the grotesque and unnatural nature of evil (Genesis 6:4; Ephesians 6:12). This imagery underscores the spiritual battle against formidable evil opposed to God's kingdom.

questions.question: What Christological theme can be associated with David’s servants defeating the giants described in 1 Chronicles 20?
options: Christ as the ultimate conqueror over sin and death
questions.correctAnswer: Christ as the ultimate conqueror over sin and death
questions.explanation: The defeat of giants by David’s servants (1 Chronicles 20:4-8) prefigures Christ’s victory over sin, Satan, and death (Colossians 2:15; Hebrews 2:14-15). David’s army is a type of the church empowered through Christ’s conquest.

questions.question: What does the weight of the Ammonite king’s crown, a talent of gold, signify in biblical theology?
options: The substantial value and glory of earthly kingdoms under God’s sovereignty
Material wealth is the highest goal of kings
Gold crowns are symbols of idolatry
The crown’s weight indicates the king’s burden of sin
questions.correctAnswer: The substantial value and glory of earthly kingdoms under God’s sovereignty
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 20:2 mentions the crown weighing a talent of gold, symbolizing the glory and value of earthly kingdoms which ultimately fall under God’s sovereign rule (Daniel 2:21; Psalm 47:8).

questions.question: How does Jonathan, David’s brother, killing the giant in Gath (1 Chronicles 20:7) contribute to understanding God’s providence in salvation history?
options: God uses faithful individuals within a covenant community to accomplish His purposes
Salvation is solely a matter of personal strength
questions.correctAnswer: God uses faithful individuals within a covenant community to accomplish His purposes
questions.explanation: Jonathan’s role (1 Chronicles 20:7) shows God’s providence working through faithful servants within the covenant community (Exodus 17:12; Judges 7:7; Acts 13:22), emphasizing communal participation in God’s redemptive work.

questions.question: What doctrinal insight is learned from David bringing 'exceeding much spoil' out of Rabbah?
options: God blesses His people materially as a sign of covenant faithfulness
Material gain is the ultimate goal of faith
Spoils of war are evidence of personal greed
Salvation is earned by military conquest
questions.correctAnswer: God blesses His people materially as a sign of covenant faithfulness
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 20:2 indicates that God blesses His people materially as a sign of His covenant faithfulness (Deuteronomy 28:1-14; Psalm 112:3), while the ultimate blessing is spiritual (Ephesians 1:3).

questions.question: What does the repeated phrase 'there was war again with the Philistines' (verses 4, 5, 6) suggest about the ongoing spiritual conflict in biblical theology?
options: The persistent struggle between God’s people and the forces opposing God’s kingdom
War was a cultural pastime with no spiritual meaning
Peace is never possible in the Old Testament
questions.correctAnswer: The persistent struggle between God’s people and the forces opposing God’s kingdom
questions.explanation: The recurring wars (1 Chronicles 20:4-6) symbolize the ongoing spiritual conflict between God’s kingdom and evil forces (Ephesians 6:10-12; Revelation 12:17). This depicts the church’s continuous battle against sin and the devil.

questions.question: How does the chapter’s account of defeating the giants align with the doctrine of spiritual authority granted to God's people?
options: God grants His people authority over spiritual and physical enemies
Victory is by human effort alone
Spiritual authority is unrelated to physical battles
questions.correctAnswer: God grants His people authority over spiritual and physical enemies
questions.explanation: The defeats of giants by David’s servants (1 Chronicles 20:4-8) illustrate God's granting of authority over enemies (Luke 10:19; Matthew 28:18). This reflects the biblical teaching that believers share in Christ’s authority over evil.

questions.question: What does David’s decision to remain in Jerusalem during the siege reveal about the relationship between the king and God’s presence?
options: The king’s role includes spiritual leadership and reliance on God’s presence
The king was afraid of battle
Military leadership must be separate from spiritual leadership
God’s presence was irrelevant to warfare
questions.correctAnswer: The king’s role includes spiritual leadership and reliance on God’s presence
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 20:1 shows David remaining in Jerusalem, emphasizing his role as spiritual leader who trusts in God’s presence (Psalm 48:1-3; 2 Chronicles 6:41-42). The king’s leadership involves both political and spiritual dimensions.

questions.question: How does the description of the giant Lahmi's spear staff as being like a weaver's beam contribute to the biblical narrative about opposition to God's people?
options: It emphasizes the overwhelming strength of opposition that God’s people face
It suggests the giant was a craftsman
It indicates the spear was lightweight and ineffective
It is a metaphor for weaving peace
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes the overwhelming strength of opposition that God’s people face
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 20:5 portrays the giant Lahmi’s spear staff as massive, symbolizing the formidable challenges faced by God's people (Nehemiah 4:17-18). This underscores the need for divine enablement to overcome such opposition (2 Corinthians 12:9).

questions.question: What ecclesiological lesson is found in the account of David and his servants defeating the giants?
options: The church, as the body of Christ, is empowered to triumph over spiritual enemies
Only individuals can fight spiritual battles
The church should avoid confrontation with evil
questions.correctAnswer: The church, as the body of Christ, is empowered to triumph over spiritual enemies
questions.explanation: The collective defeat of giants by David and his servants (1 Chronicles 20:8) reflects the church’s corporate victory through Christ (Ephesians 4:11-16; 1 Corinthians 12:12-27), emphasizing unity and empowerment by the Spirit.

questions.question: What does the destruction of Rabbah and the taking of spoils teach about God's justice in salvation history?
options: God executes justice against nations opposing His covenant people
questions.correctAnswer: God executes justice against nations opposing His covenant people
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 20:1-3 portrays the destruction of Rabbah as divine justice against enemies of God's people. This is consistent with God's righteous judgment throughout Scripture (Psalm 9:7-8; Romans 12:19) while also pointing forward to ultimate justice in Christ (Revelation 19:11-21).
